user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_notify:
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
...
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
...
void metal_sys_finish(void)
{

	/* Shutdown IRQ handling */
	metal_linux_irq_shutdown();
	metal_linux_bus_finish();
	close(_metal.pagemap_fd);

}
...
static int irq_notify_fd
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the fragments most likely to be relevant to an unreachable-code investigation: the notify function itself, the global notify fd declaration, the logging macro (which uses a GCC statement-expression and could affect control flow/macro expansion), the IRQ set-enable routine (contains early return and a notify call), the IRQ shutdown path (sets stop flag, notifies, then joins — code after pthread_join could be effectively unreachable if the thread never exits), and the system finish sequence that depends on shutdown. Other code in the provided snippets does not need further investigation for MISRA Rule 2.1: simple assignments, condition checks that plainly lead to either a return or normal continuation (no dead branches), straightforward calls to close() and mutex ops, and the write() call in metal_linux_irq_notify which returns to the caller — none of these show statically unreachable statements or syntactic constructs that would make subsequent code unreachable. Therefore only the listed fragments warrant deeper scrutiny for potential unreachable-code issues.
